content:
The problem is original and would perfectly fit a CoC, EXCEPT for a reverse !

However I agree with Niako that the input is confusing.
"I like the way it is right now" is not an objectively acceptable argument to keep it that way.
djjeck suggestion seems the best to me for readability:
One line per bus stop, thus allowing the line to only contain a 0 if no one gets in.
Upvoted but can't approve yet.
Agree with Niako. Not sure why we need the 2nd line ("1 2 2"). I guess it is for languages which requires it.

I think it would be less confusing to format the inputs (and the stub accordingly) like this (example based on the first test):
3
1 2 2
1
2 1
1 3
(moreover the current stub is wrong as "read P:word(512)" only reads the first value of the line in some languages, it should be "string" instead of "word")

The notations in the problem statement are very confusing. The problem description uses N as an index while S is the index of last stop IIUC. Yet in the input section, N becomes the total number of stops in line 1 and reused in the constraints section as such. Also, in the code S actually represents the list in line 2.

I also do not quite understand the example. The last entry of line 3 is 4, which means the person at stop 2 needs to stay for another 4 stops. Isn't the terminus supposed to be at 'stop 3'?

There are 10 people but 11 entries in the second array for the "Usual route validator" test (04).
Also, "each people" => "each person".

S is not an index here, it's the value of each element of the list given in line 2. I made a mistake about the last constraint which should have been 0 < Time duration for each person <= "N" and not "S" and about the example, so I'll fix that for sure (besides that, even with a nice code it would change nothing)

As I said, it would have been 3 and not 4, so that would mean that specific guy would stay "in theory" for 3 stops. Since that duration value is greater than the value of the remaining stops (3 > 1), that means he will stay until the end of the line.

Nothing really much tricky here though..

I can understand your suggestion but I like the way it is right now, Plus that would mean stops without anyone on it wouldn't be possible

Fixing the stub, long time I didn't create a CG contribution lol

I also don't like the input. I would expect having to read one line per bus stop.
If having to match the inputs of line 2 and 3 is the interesting part of the problem, it should be the main part of the statement, otherwise it feels like the input has been given in a convoluted way just to annoy you.
How is this input?
3
1 1
2 2 1
2 1 3
First line is N, then N lines follow, in which the first element is how many passengers, and then a list of how many stops each passenger stays. This allows for 0 passengers at a stop.

"The terminus is located after the last station S given."  Many people would interpret this sentence as S is the last station. 
"A list of N integers S space-separated ..." Here, a normal interpretation of 'S' would be the number of spaces. If S refers to the list, the sentence should be "A space-separated list S consisting of N integers ..."
In general, the English text needs to be improved.

"Since that duration value is greater than the value of the remaining stops (3 > 1), that means he will stay until the end of the line." This is not in the problem statement at all. Neither is it intuitive from the problem's context (who would interpret the input duration as an arbitrary number that is greater than or equal to the actual duration?). It is not easy for people to grasp that logic which is the key to solve the problem. It would be nice if the inputs can be changed to the actual duration with the (N+1)th stop as the terminus. If you do not want that, at least the logic needs to be clearly explained in the problem statement.

Overall improved the statement according to your feedback
Actually, I like it the way that it CAN be greater than the remaining stops, so I added a sentence describing it.

Thanks :)

"The terminus is located after the last given station (S+1)." This sentence still refers to 'S' as an index. You may double-check all occurrences of 'S' and make sure it refers to the same thing (e.g., the list of stops, not a single stop or an index).
